newsitem.title: USA: Computer Associates rises on earnings outlook.
newsitem.headline: Computer Associates rises on earnings outlook.

text.p: Shares of Computer Associates International Inc jumped as much as 14 percent Thursday after the software company said its fourth-quarter earnings likely will be better than Wall Street expected.
Computer Associates, the biggest developer of corporate software, also told investors that its European operations -- the cause of a shortfall last quarter -- have been improved.
Shares of Computer Associates, based in Islandia, New York, rose 3-7/8 to 47-7/8. The stock, which traded as high as 50 earlier, was the most active on the New York Stock Exchange.
After the market closed Wednesday, CA, the third-biggest U.S. software company, said it expects to report earnings per share of $0.90 for the quarter ended March 31.
Wall Street expected it to earn $0.86 a share, according to an analysts' survey by Zacks Investment Research.
The company also said fourth-quarter revenue will be about $1.2 billion, also better than Wall Street forecasts.
"My expectation, given sales in the pipeline, is that we'll see some pretty bullish quarters to come," Sanjay Kumar, Computer Associates' president and chief operating officer, said in an interview.
Computer Associates shares have languished in the past few months because the company had lower-than-expected revenue in the third quarter. It blamed weak sales in Europe.
Kumar said in December that it would take six months for the company to recover. Computer Associates is now three months into the recovery and doing well, Kumar said Wednesday.

"I cautioned people that we're not out of the wood yet," he said. The company still has to improve its European sales through resellers, handle accounts of big customers better and push its computer network management software more aggressively in Europe, he said.
The company specializes in developing software to manage the operations of mainframe computers and huge corporate networks.
The company said revenue for the year ended March 31, 1997, will be slightly over $4 billion, about 15 percent higher than the previous year.
